## Linear port-Hamiltonian descriptor systems
In electrical engineering applications, the need for descriptor systems arise naturally. We will use a modified version of the following Definition given by Mehrmann & Morandin in @mehrmannStructurepreserving2019 in combination with the approach of Strehle in @strehleFramework2024 and/or @strehleUnified2022. This section only consideres linear descriptor systems with a possibly non-linear resistive structure $r(\nabla H(x))$.

::: {.qp-theorem}
**Definition: port-Hamiltonian descriptor system**

Consider a time interval $\mathbb{T}:=[0,T]\subset\mathbb{R}$, $T>0$, a state space $\mathcal{X}\subseteq\R^n$ and extended state space $\mathcal{S}:=\T\times\mathcal{X}$. A port-Hamiltonian descriptor system (or pHDAE) is a system of differential (-algebraic) equations of the form
        \begin{align*}
            E\dot{x} &= (J-R)\nabla H(x) - r(\nabla H(x)) + Gu + Kd,\\
            y &= G^T\nabla H(x),\\
            z &= K^T\nabla H(x),
        \end{align*}
        with a Hamiltonian function $\mathcal{H}(x):\mathcal{X}\to\R$, where $x(t)\in\mathcal{X}$ is the state, $u(t)\in\R^{m_1}, y(t)\in\R^{m_1}$, are the controllable input and output, $d(t)\in\R^{m_2}, z(t)\in\R^{m_2}$ are the uncontrollable interaction ports.
:::

Test

::: {.qp-theorem}
**Remark**

We can equivalently write
        \begin{align*}
            E\dot{x} + r &= (J-R)\nabla H(x) + B\tilde{u},\\
            \tilde{y} &= B^T\nabla H(x),
        \end{align*}
        with $\tilde{u} = [u\; d]^T\in\R^m$, $m=m_1+m_2$, $\tilde{y} = [y\; z]^T\in\R^m$
:::
